name: Peperino di Albano
alternate_name: lapis albanus, Peperino di Marino; Albanae
petrographic_details: colata di fango piroclastica; quarried from a volcanic-debris flow deposit
appearance: The term "peperino" refers to gray tufi from the Lazio with parts of crystals both white (leucite and analcime) and dark (biotite, pirocene).
quarry_location: Colli Albani district; from the Crater of Lake Albano, Deposits contained within a close area around eruptive vents; quarried at Castrimoenum, near modern-day Marino, and used locally
archaeological_sources: Sabatine district;  taken up to 13 km from the Via Tiberina, no longer available because the land has been covered in more recent formations.; "Near Grotta Oscura and northward along Via Tiberina"; Pyroclastic flows traveled far from their eruptive vents, meaning the rock was widespread and varied from one site to the other.; Local use, mostly at Rome
primary_sources: Vitruvius (2.7.1) groups Albanae among the "soft and yielding" (molles) stones of Rome [[De Architectura, in 4, 410]]
notes: Composed of fine grain with phillipsite, cabasite, and calcite, including diverse fragments of leucite lava, vulcanic rock, magmatic crystals, white calcari, and more.
dates_of_use: Accessible after the construction of the Via Appia, 312 BCE; used in the late Republic and early Imperial Period

name: Pietra Gabina
alternate_name: lapis gabinus; Gabine tufa, sperone;but the latter term should be avoided due to ambiguity
petrographic_details: deposito piroclastico idromagmatico; quarried from a pyroclastic surge deposit
appearance: Dark and greyish. stratified into levels , whose superficial layers erode at different speeds and in different ways; The only stratified Roman tufo
quarry_location: Colli Albani district; the crater of Castiglione; near the old city of Gabi; Deposits contained within a close area around eruptive vents; local use, mostly at Rome
archaeological_sources: Ponte Palatino; Base of the Tabularium below the Campdohlio, part of the Cloaca Maxima, base of the tomb of Cecelia Metella, the perimiter wall of the Augustan Forum and many praefurnia of the Roman baths
primary_sources: Strabo Geography 5.3.10-11
notes: Coherent and compact, with good physico-mechanical characteristics. Known among the Romans for being resistant to fire;Coarse-grained levels feature dark gray lava fragments and crystals, while finer layers contain clay, pumice, and accretionary lapilli
dates_of_use: Late Republic and early Imperial Period

name: Tufo del Palatino
alternate_name: Granular grey tufa, Peperino della Via Flaminia, Peperino Grigio; Tufo pisolitico, tufo granulare grigio, cappellaccio; but the latter should be avoided for ambiguity
petrographic_details: Colata piroclastica idromagmatica; quarried from ignimbrite, an unstructured deposit produced by pyroclastic flow
appearance: Yellowish-grey with some green tones. Compact structure, fine granulometry of components, superficially inconsistent, . Composed of a heterogeneous association of volcanic fragments and sediment, immersed in a partly zeolite and often argillated glassy matrix [[1, 287]]
quarry_location: Colli Albani district; Base of the Campidoglio Base of the Palatino; Found at the bases of hills; Aventine; used at Rome
archaeological_sources: Cut-stone podia of the Regia (6th and 7th centuries BCE), Auguraculum (6th century BCE), Temple of Juno Moneta (345 BCE);  Still found in Servian walls, early Forum structures, Temple of Magna Mater sul Palatino, Capitoline Jove's temple (510 BC), Temple of S. Omobono (500 BC), Temple of Saturn (501-493 BC), foundations of lapis niger (450-390 BC);   Teatro Marcello [[1, 278]], temples of Numa Pompilio (715-673 BC);  Used in 7km-long wall built c. 578-535 AD;  used often in Monarchic period
notes: soft, early building material; Of "modest" mechanical quality and inconsistent; discrete mechanical strength, surface quickly dries and crumbles when exposed to air and water, with drastic dimunition of mechanical characteristics compared to waterlogged samples in the lab; Not to be confused with Grottarossa Pyroclastic Sequence subunit a, although both have been referred to as cappellaccio. this rock has more lava fragments, no sanidine, and minimal biotite; while the Peperino della Flaminia variety was much stronger than other varieties, there is no evidence of its use in construction
dates_of_use: Mostly used during the seventh through fifth centuries BCE; Use continued until 390 CE when it was substituted by rock with stronger mechanical charactaristics and better aesthetics

name: Tufo di Tuscolo
alternate_name: Sperone, but this ambiguous term should be avoided
appearance: Brown-gray. Rich in fragments of lava and crystal
quarry_location: Colli Albani district; Monte Tusculo in the Colli Albani, active until the first century BC.; Deposits contained within a close area around eruptive vents; Used locally, mostly at Rome
archaeological_sources: Colosseum, Tabularium of the Campidoglio, Church of S. Clemente;Theater of Marcellus (23-11 BCE), reinforced with travertine in the Colosseum
primary_sources: Pliny cites Varro as saying tufo di Tuscolo can be broken up by fire [[Natural History 36.29]]
notes: Up to 50% lava fragments; "The most robust lithic-crystal tuff building stone available in Rome"
dates_of_use: Late Republic and early Imperial Period

name: Tufo Giallo della Via Tiberina
alternate_name: lapis ruber, lapis pallens, Tufo giallo di Grotta Oscura; tufo giallo porosa
petrographic_details: Colata piroclastica; quarried from ignimbrite, an unstructured deposit produced by pyroclastic flow
age: 548,000 years old +/- 4,000 (upper eruptive subunits), 561,000 +/- 4,000 years old (lower eruptive subunits)
appearance: Yellow, with some dark grey. Made of yellow pumice, including carbon and more; Glassy and porous, "poorly to moderately cemented"
quarry_location: Sabatine district;taken up to 13 km from the Via Tiberina, no longer available because the land has been covered in more recent formations.;"Near Grotta Oscura and northward along Via Tiberina"; Pyroclastic flows traveled far from their eruptive vents, meaning the rock was widespread and varied from one site to the other.; Local use, mostly at Rome
archaeological_sources: Many monuments in the Forum: foundations of Basilica Aemelia, the Tempio Rotondo in the Foro Boario, and the temple of the Magna Mater. It is also present in large quantities in caementa and in opus reticulatum throughout the city; Used as a component of coarse aggregate in concrete during the Imperial Period; in the Colosseum (70-80 CE), Forum of Caesar (54-29 BCE), Pantheon (118-125 CE)
primary_sources: Vitruvius groups "lapidicinis Pallensibus" among the "soft and yielding" (molles) stones of Rome [[De Architectura 2.7.1, in 4, 410]]; he warns that they are weakened when exposed to salt/frost/rain/heat [[2.7.2]]
notes: Notable chemical homogeneity, of 41-52%, famous for the ease with which it can be worked and for its durability.
dates_of_use: Quarried after Roman conquest of Fidenae and Veio in 426 and 396 BCE

name: Tufo Giallo di Prima Porta
appearance: Yellow-gray, glassy, "small, grayish-orange pumice fragments"
quarry_location: Sabatine District; South of the deposits of Tufo Giallo della Via Tiberina, along Via Tiberina and Via Flaminia, as well as at Prima Porta
archaeological_sources: Not used as dimension stone, but sometimes used in coarse aggregate as part of concrete in the Forum of Caesar
notes: Lots of joints and fractures; consists mostly of chabazite cement with up to 50% glass matrix

name: Tufo lionato
alternate_name: lapis ruber, Tufo litoide Lionato, Tufo dell'Aniene, Tufo di Monteverde;, Anio, lapidicinis Rubris;
petrographic_details: Colata piroclastica; quarried from ignimbrite, an unstructured deposit produced by pyroclastic flow
appearance: Aniene River varieties: light brown, well consolidated, 12-20% lava with yellowish-brown pumice fragments; varieties south of Rome: light brown to grayish orange, less consolidated, <10% lava, light brown to dark yellowish-orange pumice fragments; Monteverde area varieties: mostly white phillipsite cement, minimal clay, varies in color
quarry_location: Colli Albani district Found at the tops of hills; On the right bank of the Tiber- what is now Monteverde;  Along the Aniene (Teverone) River, which flows from the Tiber; quarried at Tor Cervara, Settecamini, Salone, and Lunghezza in the 2nd century BCE;  occasionally, in small quantities Tufo Rosso with black spots is found in caves in the area now called Fidene, about 10 KM north of Rome along the Tiber;  Base of the Capitoline Hill; Pyroclastic flows traveled far from their eruptive vents, meaning the rock was widespread and varied from one site to the other.;  Local use, mostly at Rome
archaeological_sources: Combined with stronger tuffs and travertine in the 1st century BCE, e.g., tabernae of the Forum of Caesar (42 BCE); Other examples: Roman forum, temples of Numa Pompilio (715-673 BC), portions of the cloaca maxima; Used in Forum: Votive deposit (6th c. BC), Temple of Concord (6th C. BC), Temple of Mars Ultor (2 C. BC), internal wall of Tabularium (78 BC), Tabernae of the Via Sacra (1st C. BC), Horrea Agrippiana (31-27 BC), Basilica Giulia (78-54 BC), the area Largo Torre Argentina; Aniene River varieties rarely used in dimension stone masonry after the Forum of Augustus, 1st century BCE; Coarse aggregate from south of Rome used in Baths of Caracalla (211-216 CE), Colosseum (after 216 CE fire)
primary_sources: Vitruvius groups "lapicidinis Rubris" among the "soft and yielding" (molles) stones of Rome [[De Architectura 2.7.1, in 4, 410]]; he warns that they are weakened when exposed to salt/frost/rain/heat [[2.7.2]]
notes: higher quality than cappellaccio; Most used tufo in all Roman monuments; Often used in typical rectangular blocks. Irregular content, irregular weight and density. Contains white analcime powder aggregate and also dark lava and light sedimentary rock, occasionally carbonized. Was considered a superior stone for its physico-mechanical characteristics. Carried along the Tiber for miles.
dates_of_use: Early Romans used the weaker, glassy varieties quarried from the Capitoline and Monteverde, while the stronger varieties quarried along the Aniene became prominent during the late 2nd century BCE

name: Tufo Rosso a Scorie Nere
alternate_name: lapis fidenae, Tufo di Fidene, Tufo Rosso Litoide, Fidenates
appearance: dark red with black slag; or, light brown with dark gray fragments
quarry_location: Sabatine district; found primarily in the quarries of Fidene about 10 km north of Rome on the Tiber; Covers a vast area. ; Isola Farnese; Castel Giubileo; Prima Porta; Saxa Rubra; local use, mostly at Rome
archaeological_sources: Used in structures of opus quadratum, in the podium of the Tempio della Concordia; podium of the Temple of Juno Moneta (345 BCE) cella walls of temples
primary_sources: Vitruvius groups Fidenates among the "soft and yielding" (molles) stones of Rome [[De Architectura 2.7.1, in 4, 410]]; he warns that they are weakened when exposed to salt/frost/rain/heat [[2.7.2]]
notes: Low load-bearing strength limited its usefulness in the Late Republic
dates_of_use: First used by the Etruscans, used by the Romans primarily between 390 and 210 BCE, and less frequently until the Imperial period;. Quarried after Roman conquest of Fidenae and Veio in 426 and 396 BCE, but not common in Late Republican buildings.

alternate_name: marmor lucullaeum; Lucullean marble, Africano Marble, Africano Lilac, Nero Africano
appearance: Brown/White/Black/Blue; or, gray-brown tinted with white, pink, red, yellow, black
quarry_location: Asia minor, Izmir, Theos; modern Turkey, under the lake of Kara Gol, 15 km NE of Teos, at Küçükkaya, 7 km north of Teos, at Turgut; exported inter-regionally
archaeological_sources: Columns: Basilica Aemilia, theater of Marcellus, Forum of Augustus, Tempio della Pace, S. Peter's Basilica, S. Giovanni in Laterano, S. Giacomo e S. Maria in Vallicella. Paving stones: S. Paolo fuori le Mura, St. Peter's, S. Croce in Jerusalem, Vittoriano. Threshold: pantheon. Fountains: Pantheon, Piazza Mattei, Babuino. Wainscoting: S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Maria della Vittoria. Architrace: Palazzo della Valle. Acquasantiere: S. Giovanni in Laterano, wall stones.
primary_sources: The extravagant consul Scaurus is said to have decorated his house with 38-foot columns
dates_of_use: Exported from Teos during the Imperial Period; per Pliny, black variety (from Melos? Chios?) introduced to Rome by L. Lucullus, consul, who lent his name to the stone, in 74 BCE

name: alabastro a pecorella
alternate_name: Alabastro a pecorella minuto, Travertine, sanguigno d'Orano.
appearance: red/brown/white
quarry_location: Algeria, Province of Orano, Aîn Tekbalet.; Bou Hanifia, 20 km SW of Mascara, Algeria
archaeological_sources: rotae: S. Clemente. Bust of Vespasian in the Museo dei Conservatori. Mirrors: piedistalli delle quattro colonne della quinta cappella a destra in S. Maria sopra Minerva. Cornices, vasche.

name: alabastro fiorito
appearance: Yellow and pink with white, brown, red stripes
quarry_location: Gölemezli, north of Hierapolis, modern Turkey
dates_of_use: "used locally and exported widely in the Roman Imperial period and possibly earlier"

name: Alwalton Marble
petrographic_details: Limestone, from the Great Oolite Group, Cornbrash
appearance: Blue-gray, hard, with lots of fossilized oyster shells
quarry_location: Quarried from the banks of the River Nene, Alwalton Lynch Escarpment, Peterborough, England; used in the Roman town of Castor nearby
archaeological_sources: In later times, commonly used in column bases, capitals, effigies, and fonts of cathedrals
notes: Sometimes confused with Purbeck Marble, which it resembles when polished

name: Ancaster Freestone
alternate_name: Ancaster Freebed
appearance: Cream to pale brown/buff, medium-grained with a few pieces of shells; composition and color vary from quarry to quarry
quarry_location: England: quarried at Glebe Quarry near Ancaster, Lincolnshire, and other quarries nearby; local and regional use
archaeological_sources: Sculptural and architectural work during Roman times; later examples include Saxon sculptures in the 7th/8th centuries CE; medieval grave slabs and effigies; postmedieval masonry at Harlaxton Manor, Wollaton Hall, and castles across England
notes: Durable and easier to carve than the harder Ancaster stones, such as Ancaster "Hard White"
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Ancaster Hard White
appearance: Pale honey to a cream colour, rough, medium-grained, well cemented, hard; composition and color vary from quarry to quarry
quarry_location: England: quarried at Glebe Quarry near Ancaster, Lincolnshire, and other quarries nearby; local and regional use
archaeological_sources: Sculptural and architectural work during Roman times; later examples include Saxon sculptures in the 7th/8th centuries CE; medieval grave slabs and effigies; postmedieval font of Nuthall St. Patrick Church in Nottinghamshire
notes: Finest grained of the Ancaster stones
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Ancaster Weatherbed
alternate_name: Ancaster Rag
appearance: Varies from cream/brown-yellow to blue/gray, "mottled and/or flecked", medium-grained with lots of shells including gastropods; many samples "show a lenticular core of blue grey limestone (often known as 'blue hearted')
quarry_location: England: quarried at Glebe Quarry near Ancaster, Lincolnshire, and other quarries nearby; local and regional use
archaeological_sources: Sculptural and architectural work during Roman times; later examples include Saxon sculptures in the 7th/8th centuries CE, medieval grave slabs, and effigies
notes: Harder than the other Ancaster stones, it comes in two varieties: the upper Red Weatherbed and the lower Brown Weatherbed
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Barnack Rag Stone
alternate_name: Barnack Stone, Barnack Mill Stone
appearance: Coarse, hard, shelly, poorly sorted, contains ooliths and shells in alternating layers as well as "sparry calcite"
quarry_location: Quarried from Roman through Medieval times at Hills and Holes quarry, Barnack, near Peterborough, Eastern England; local and regional use
archaeological_sources: Ashlar masonry; later examples include parts of Ely and Peterborough Cathedrals
notes: Most common of three varieties of Barnack Stone; the other two were used in carving and rubblestone walling
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Beer Stone
appearance: White/gray-white, sometimes tinted green; fine and well sorted, containing shells and some quartz and glauconite
quarry_location: Thought to have been quarried underground at Beer Quarry, near Seaton, SW England
archaeological_sources: Roman examples include the wall quoins (outside angles), flue linings, and floor supports of the Bath House at Seaton Roman Villa in Devon
notes: Suitable for carving, "well suited for interior work"

name: bigio antico
alternate_name: Marmor batthium, marmor lesbium, bigio dell'Asia minore.
appearance: Grey/Beige/White
quarry_location: Asia Minor, Island of Lesbos/Teos; widely exported during the Imperial Period, Turkey, 19 km NE of Ephesos, at Hasançavuslar (exported inter-regionally), Turkey, 2.4 km NE of Iznik in Bithynia et Pontus (local use), Turkey, Panayirdağ, near Ephesos (local use)
archaeological_sources: Columns: portico of S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, atrium and porta maggiore of S. Croce in Jerusalem, Chapel of S. Benedetto in S. Paolo fuori le Mura, Capella Salviati di S. Gregorio Magno. S. Clemente and S. Lorenzo in Borgo. Paving stones: S. Croce in Jerusalem, S. Clemente. Fonts: S. Giovanni in Laterano, S. Croce in Jerusalem, S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, S. Clemente. revetement stones.
primary_sources: Pliny the Elder mentions as a sculpting stone, noting its slightly blue tint
dates_of_use: Exported from Lesbos during the Imperial Period

name: Black Pasture Stone
appearance: Yellow-brown-pink with brown specks, tough, hard, fine- to medium-grained, granular
quarry_location: Quarried from the area around Chollerford, Northern England, near Milecastle 26 on Hadrian's Hall and the Roman fort, Cilurnum [[6]]
archaeological_sources: Hadrian's Wall, c. 120 CE; according to J. Watson, also used in the piers of the bridge that spanned the North Tyne, possibly a reference to the Aelian Bridge between Newcastle and Gateshead, constructed 122 CE
notes: Regarded as an excellent building stone

name: Breccia corallina
alternate_name: marmor sagarium
appearance: red/orange/white
quarry_location: Asia Minor, Verzirhan, Bilecik; also quarried at Toprak Alinmis, Balıklıova, Karga Tepe, and Azmak Tepe, on the Karaburum Peninsula, modern Turkey
archaeological_sources: Columns: Atrium Vestae, S. Prisca, S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, S. Croce in Gerusalemme, S. Sebastiano, Chiesa del Gesù, S. Maria in Aracoeli, Palazzo Rospigliosi. Paving stones: X. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Pietro in Vaticano, S. Clemente. Wall stones: Atrium Vestae, Confessional in S. Giovanni in Laterano. Vases, Cups.
dates_of_use: Regionally exported from Verzirhan starting in the late 1st century BCE

name: breccia di Aleppo
appearance: gray/brown
quarry_location: Quarried at Karies, just inland from Latomi, Chios, Greece, and exported widely
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Breccia di Sciro
alternate_name: semesanto, marmor scyreticum, breccia di Settebasi o Settebassi, breccia orientale.
appearance: Brown/Pink/Purple/White
quarry_location: Greece, Aegean Sea, Island of Skyros; quarried at Cape Oros, Cape Marmoro, Haghios Panteleimonas, Koprisses, Koulori, Renes, Tres Boukes, Skipoula island, south of Skyros, at Cape Kolona, Valaxa island, south of Skyros, at Cape Latomio,  similar variety of breccia found in Turkey, 8 km east of Teos, at Beyler (local use, possibly exported)
archaeological_sources: Wall stones: S. Paolo fuori le Mura, Gregorian chapel in the Basilica of S. Maria Maggiore, S. Maria degli Angeli, S. Lorenzo in Mirando, S. Pietro in Vinvoli, Chiesa del Gesù, S. Maria Maddalena in Campo Marzio (semesanto). Columns: Synagogue, S. Luigi de' Francesi, S. Clemente. Paving Stones, Cornices.
primary_sources: Strabo compares Scyrian marble to cipollino dell'Eubea and pavonazetto and claims that Rome was "adorned both at public and private expense" with "monolithic columns and great slabs" of the breccia
dates_of_use: Exported widely from Tres Boukes and Renes during the Imperial Period, and inter-regionally elsewhere throughout Roman times

name: breccia di Seravezza
alternate_name: breccia medicea, mischio; breccia di Serravezza antica; breccia violetta marble
appearance: yellow/purple/blue/orange
quarry_location: taly, Tuscany, Monte Corchia, Stazzema, Lucca.; exported regionally
archaeological_sources: Paving and wall stones: St. Peter's. Colonette.

name: breccia dorata
alternate_name: marmi breccia dorata
appearance: golden yellow
quarry_location: Quarried at Molli, Tegoia, and Montarrenti, near Sienna, Italy; local use, possibly exported
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: breccia nuvolata
appearance: Yellow
quarry_location: Quarried at Harmanköy, south of Gölpazari, modern Turkey; "exported regionally and inter-regionally in the Roman period"

name: breccia quintilina
appearance: Dark brown…with shades of black and swirling white veins
quarry_location: Quarried at Levanto, southern Liguria, Italy; local and regional use
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: breccia rossa appenninica
appearance: Pink-brown/pink-red
quarry_location: Quarried at Pegazzano-Biassa near La Spezia, Liguria, Italy, and exported in small amounts to Rome
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Breccia verde d'Egitto
alternate_name: breccia verde antica ("ancient green breccia"), breccia verde dure ("hard green breccia"), breccia universale ("universal breccia") and centopietre ("100 stones"), lapis hexecontalithos ("stone of 60 stones), lapis hecatontalithos ("stone of 100 stones"); breccia Fawakhir, breccia Egiziana
appearance: green/grey/red; sandy with rounded pebbles; "hints of black and brown"
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian desert/ Mons Basanites/ Uadi Hammamat; near the modern cities of Qena and Luxor
archaeological_sources: Columns: Antiquarium of the Forum, S. Maria in Aracoeli, Magistral room in the Palazzo dei Conservatori. Floors: Baptistry of S. Paolo fuori le Mura; Vases; Basins
dates_of_use: "Exported in Roman Imperial Period but very rare"

name: breccia verde di Sparta
appearance: Dark green, with gray/green granitic/porphyritic pieces
quarry_location: Quarried at Sparta, central Lakonia, Greece
dates_of_use: Probably used in Roman Imperial period but rare before Late Antiquity when exported inter regionally

name: Spanish broccatello
alternate_name: broccatello di Spagna, jaspi de la Cinta, lumachella, broccatello; Brocatello Viola,Sherry Brocatello,Jaspi de Tortosa,Castellon Sherry, Sherry Gold, Golden Shell, Castellon Brocatello,Tortosa Sherry
appearance: red/orange/yellow/white
quarry_location: Spain, Catalonia, Tortosa.; quarried at Barranc de La Llet and "exported as far as Rome in the Roman Imperial period"
archaeological_sources: Wall stones: S. Paolo fuori le Mura, apse of S. Giovanni in Laterano, S. Clemente, S. Maria Maddalena in Campo Marzio, S. Gregorio Magno. Paving stones: villa dei Gordiani, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, Mirrors: cappella paolina a S. Maria Maggiore; cornices: S. Pietro in Vincoli, columns, S. Spirito a via Giulia, S. Maria Maggiore, SS. Cosma e Damiano. Balustrades: S. Peter's, sarcophagi.

name: broccatellone
appearance: pink and white
quarry_location: Turkey: Çakmakli, 24 km NE of Manisa, and Gerence, Karaburum peninsula; probably exported

name: selce di Roma
alternate_name: lava, basalts, selce romana, silex durus; Capo di Bove Lava
age: Capo di bove 280,000 years old;or, 277,000 +/- 2,000 years old
appearance: dark gray, compact, occasional gas holes, fine grain with few visible crystals
quarry_location: Volcanic district of the Colli Albani, Capo di Bove- the most important ancient source, quarry along the Appia Antica, quarries along the Via Laurentina (more modern), Pantano, Lago Regillo in the Castelli Romani near Tuscolo
archaeological_sources: Pavement of streets, using bloth large and small blocks (basoli, quadrucci, sampietrini). Often used as aggregate in cement, often used to grind wheat because of its roughness and durability
primary_sources: Vitruvius (2.7.1) mentions "siliceae" as hard ("durae") stones; Jackson interprets silex to mean specifically Rome's lava flows, although it can also be a general term for any hard stone
notes: Low porousness, hard, resistant to chemical alteration
dates_of_use: Used in every age

name: cipollino verde
alternate_name: Eubean Onion-Marble; marmor carystium; marmor styrium; marmo euboico; cipollino dell'Eubea; cipollino (antique de) Greco, Styra Green, cipollino antico, Stouraitikon,Karystia lithos
appearance: Green/white
quarry_location: Greece, Southern Eubeoea, Karystia.; quarried at Aetos, Kylindroi, near Karystos, Mount Kionia and Oberes, near Marmari, Mount Pyrgari, near Nimborio, Myloi, Myrtia, Mount Vrethela, near Marmari, Styra, similar varieties in Spain and Portugal
archaeological_sources: Columns: Temple of Romulus, Temple of Antoninus and Faustina, Forum of Augustus, Portico of Agrippa, casa di Mamurra sul Celio, S. Paolo and S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, S. Clemente, S. Lorenzo in Mirando, Cappella Salviati in S. Gregorio Magno, Immaculate Conception a Piazza di Spagna. Wall stones: S. Sabina, SS. Giovanni e Paolo. Paving stones: Basilica Aemilia, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Maria Maddalena in Campo Marzio, SS. Giovanni e Paolo. Statuary, basins.
primary_sources: Pliny posits that the stone composed the columns of the house of Mamurra, "the first person at Rome who covered the whole of the walls of his house with marble"; Strabo, Geography: 10.1.6
notes: Mineralogical composition: Calcite:95%, Quartz:3%, Muscovite mica:0.2%, Chlorite:0.6%, Others:1%
dates_of_use: Local use from the Classical period (dates?), vast exportation during the Imperial Period

name: cipollino mandolato
alternate_name: marbre campan; griottes; griottes mauves de Campan, cipollino mandolato verde; Marbre Amygdalarie, Payolle Campan,Campan Melange
petrographic_details: calcare nodulare; nodular limestone also marble
appearance: green/yellow; Two varieties of marble at Campan quarry: griottes mauves de Campan was violet-pink, cipollino mandolato verde was green
quarry_location: France, Pirenei centrali, Espiadet-Campan.; quarried at Cabane de la Hosse and exported regionally in Roman times
archaeological_sources: Stones: S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Pietro in Vincoli, S. Gregorio Magno, Capella Torlonia in S. Giovanni in Laterano. crustae in Teatro di Marcello. Mirrors: Confessional in S. Maria Maggiore. Colonnette, Balustrades in Chiesa del Gesù, S. Giovanni in Laterano. Paving stones in Palazzo Rondinini, Mattonelle.

name: Cipollino rosso
alternate_name: Red onion-stone, rosso brecciato, red brecciato; marmor carium o iassense, iassense brecciato, Africanone
appearance: Red/pink/white
quarry_location: Asia minor, Abkuk, Kiyikislaçik (Milas- antica lasos); local, regional, inter-regional use, also quarried at Asin, in Karia, and used locally during the Imperial Period, exported between regions in small amounts
archaeological_sources: Floors: Pauline chapel, Confessional in Santa Maria Maggiore, S. Giovanni in Laterano. Columns: S. Luigi de' Francesi. crustae, pasamenti, steps, statues.
primary_sources: Perhaps the white marble mentioned by Strabo as being quarried at Mylasa (Milas) and used to construct temples and other public buildings in the city
dates_of_use: Imperial Period at Asin, no dates for Abkuk

name: cottanello antico
alternate_name: cotanella, cotanella moderna, rosso chiaro di Cottanello, cottanello sabino, pietra persichina
appearance: orange/brown/white/purple
quarry_location: Italy, Lazio, Rieti Cottanello; exported regionally
archaeological_sources: Columns: S. Peter's, S. Maria degli Angeli, S. Agnese in Agone, S. Andrea al Quirinale, S. Maria Maddalena in Campo Marzio, S. Giovanni de' Fiorentini. Stones: cappella Ss. Sacramento in S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Maria Maddalena in Campo Marzio, S. Clemente, S. Gregorio Magno. Balustrades: S. Pietro in Vincoli. Funerary monuments: S. Maria Maggiore. Mattonelle, crustae.
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Doddington Stone
alternate_name: Doddington Sandstone
petrographic_details: Sandstone from the Fell Sandstone Group
appearance: yellowish brown/pink, specked with light brown-gray to deep purple-pink; medium-grained, hard, cross-bedded
quarry_location: Quarried from around Doddington, Northumberland, in NE England
archaeological_sources: Possibly used to build Hadrian's Wall, 120 CE
notes: Up to 97% quartz grains; the mineral haematite (iron oxide) is responsible for the "gentle pink colour"

name: Egyptian Alabaster
alternate_name: lapis alabastrites, lapis onyx, alabastro cotognino, alabastro venato, alabastro onice; alabastro orientale o Egiziano; Alabaster Gold, Alabastro Beni Suef, Asyut Alabastro
appearance: alternating bands of opaque white, fine-grained calcite and translucent, yellowish-brown, coarse-grained calcite, and occasionally massive amber-brown calcite [[2]]; Pliny claims the best variety is "of a honey colour…covered with spots curling in whirls" [[Natural History 36.12]]
quarry_location: Eastern Desert of Egypt, mostly within 25 km of the Nile Valley, with Roman quarries at Wadi el-Garawi near Helwan city; Wadi Araba; el-Qawatir near el-Minya; and Hatnub, SE of el-Amarna ruins; similar stone quarried at /exported from Akhisar, in modern Turkey
archaeological_sources: Columns: theatre of Balbo, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Prassede. Floors: temple of Marte Ultore, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Giovanni in Laterano, S. Maria Maggiore, S. Pietro in Vaticano, S. Clemente, Chiesa della Vittoria, S. Carlo ai Catinari. Urns, Vases
primary_sources: Pliny the Elder describes the stone "alabastrites", used for jars and plasters, found near Thebes, Egypt and Damascus, Syria; also mentioned in Natural History, 36.43
notes: The name "alabaster" is a misnomer named after alabastron jars; geologically, alabaster is a type of the rock gypsum

name: fior di pesco
alternate_name: marmor chalcidium, marmor molossium, rosso di Eretria; Eretria Rose/Red
appearance: Red/White/Pink/Purple
quarry_location: Greece, Euboea, Eretria.; also at Lepoura, just east of Aliveri on Euboea
archaeological_sources: Wall stones: S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Giovanni in Laterano, S. Antonio dei Portoghesi, S. Pietro in Vincoli, SS. Giovanni e Paolo. Paving stones: S. Pietro in Vincoli. Columns: S. Antonio dei Portoghesi. Basins
notes: 92% calcite, 2% dolomite, 3% quartz, 3% clay minerals
dates_of_use: Local use from the Archaic period, vast exportation during the Roman Empire

name: gabbro eufotide
alternate_name: granito verde plasmato
appearance: Four varieties, ranging from medium- to coarse-grained, all mottled white/light gray/green
quarry_location: Near Wadi Maghrabiya, Eastern Desert of Egypt
notes: Exported in small amounts
dates_of_use: 1st to 2nd century CE

name: giallo antico
alternate_name: marmor numidicum, marmo libico; Rouge Chemtou, Chemtou Marbre,Pink Chemtou, Marbre Marron Chemtou, Jaune Antique de Chemtou
appearance: yellow/brown/orange.
quarry_location: Tunis, Numidia; Gebel Chemtou in Africa procunsularis, at Simitthus, with only 0.4 km^2 of quarrying area, shipped along the Bagradas/Medjerda River or by land to Carthage; regional and inter-regional use, similar varieties of yellow marble used locally in Algeria, near Oran, and Djebel Ichkeul, Tunisia, during the Imperial Period
archaeological_sources: Paving stones: Curia al Foro, Trajanic Forum, Pantheon, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Pietro in Vaticano, S. Sabina. Blocks in arch of Augustus in the Forum. Columns: pantheon, arch of Constantine, Forum of Augustus, S. Giovanni in Laterano, S. Maria Maddalena in Campo Marzio. Statues in palazzo Altemps. Cornices: S. Lorenzo in Mirando, S. Clemente, S. Gregorio Magno. Balustrades: S. Pietro in Montorio. Vasche: S. Stefano Rotondo. Wall stones, mattonelle, capitals;  Like other precious marbles, largely restricted to public/imperial use
primary_sources: C. Suetonius Tranquilus, Divius Julius 85; Pliny the Elder, Natural History: 5.2.22, 36.8
dates_of_use: Occupation at Simitthus from the 100s to 200s CE; very hard to date; Pliny traces the first use at Rome to the doorsills of M. Lepidus, who was consul in 78 BCE

name: giallo tigrato
quarry_location: Quarried at Montecalvo, near Rieti, Lazio, Italy; local and regional use during Roman times

name: Granito bianco e nero
alternate_name: Black and white granite; marmor tiberianum; granito bianco e nero del Cairo
appearance: blue/black/white; two varieties: yellowish-white/light gray, greenish-black crystals from lower quarry; light gray, greenish-black grains from upper quarry
quarry_location: Eastern egyptian desert; Uadi Barud, Ras Barud; a.k.a. Tiberiane
archaeological_sources: Columns: S. Saba, S.Prassede, Palazzo Altemps, salita Borgia. Floor inlays: eagle in the crest of S. Giovanni in Laterano, triclinium of the Domus Flavia and Domus Tiberiana.
primary_sources: Pliny the Elder was likely referring to this when he mentioned the Tiberian marble with white streaks
notes: Exported in small quantities
dates_of_use: Quarry possibly founded under Tiberius, early first century CE; lasted through the 2nd century CE

name: granito bigio grafico
appearance: gray, "with black and white inclusions"
quarry_location: Quarried at Hadjret-en-Nous, 14 km west of Cherchel, Algeria; used locally, exported
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Granito del Foro
alternate_name: Forum Granite, marmor claudianum; lapis psaronius; granito bianco e nero del Foro
appearance: white/black/green; medium-grained with streaks of dark minerals
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian desert; Gebel Fatira; Mons Claudianus - widespread quarries north-northeast of Wadi Umm Hussein, covering over 9 km^2; mainly exported to Italy
archaeological_sources: Columns: Temple of Venus and Rome in the Forum, Traianic Forum; baths of Caracalla; Pantheon; baths of Diocletian; S. Prassede, S. Clemente. Basins: Piazza Farnese, Piazza del Quirinale: pavement stones: S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, S. Maria degli Angeli, Vittoriano. Rotae
dates_of_use: First known date of quarrying was 68 CE, peak during the early 100s, ending before mid-200s CE

name: granito bianco e nero gabino
alternate_name: white and black granite gabino, granito del Uadi Fawakhir/Granite of Uadi Fawakhir, granitello bigio
appearance: purple/pink/white/blue; fine- to medium-grained
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian desert; Uadi Fawakhir
archaeological_sources: Columns: S.Croce in Jerusalem, S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, Palazzo della Cancelleria
dates_of_use: All examples are post-antiquity; exported in small amounts in the Imperial Period

name: granito della colonna
alternate_name: Granite of the Column, granito della flagellazione (granite of flagellation)
appearance: light gray, light pink, green-black, coarse-grained
quarry_location: Eastern Desert of Egypt, Wadi Umm Shegilat near Gebel Abu el-Hasan; exported to Rome in small amounts
dates_of_use: 1st to 2nd century CE

name: granito dell'Elba
alternate_name: granito grigio dell'Elba
appearance: Medium-grained, gray tinted with pink, green, white
quarry_location: Quarried from Monte Capanne, Elba; local and regional use, esp. in Italy
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: granito nero
alternate_name: granito nero di Siene/black granite of Syene, granito bigio/nero antico ("ancient gray/black granite"); Aswan Black Granite
appearance: Black; coarse- to medium-grained with white/light gray/light green/pink phenocrysts (crystals), often porphyritic or gneissoid
quarry_location: Southern Egypt, Aswan
notes: Quarried along with its more common counterpart, granito rosso di Aswan; samples can lie on a spectrum between the two
dates_of_use: "Exported regionally from Pharaonic period and inter-regionally in Roman period"

name: Granito rosso antico
alternate_name: granito rosso di Aswan/Red Aswan Granite, sienite; marmor thebaicus; granito egiziano; marmor syeniten, lapis syenites (Stone of Syene), lithos pyrrhopoecilus (red-spotted stone), lapis Aethiopicus (stone of Ethiopia); psaranus
appearance: red/purple/brown; coarsed-grained, often gneissoid or porphyritic
quarry_location: Southern Egypt (Aswan)
archaeological_sources: Obelisks: Antinous, Pantheon, Montecitorio, Vatican. Columns: Pantheon, Tempio della Pace, portico of S. Maria Maggiore, atrium of S. Croce in Jerusalem, S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, S. Giovanni in Laterano. Floor: S. Maria Maggiore, S. Paolo fuori le Mura; basins, statues.
primary_sources: Pliny claims that specks of gold are sometimes embedded within this stone
notes: Quarried along with its less common counterpart, granito nero; samples can lie on a spectrum between the two
dates_of_use: Exported regionally from Pharaonic period and inter-regionally in Roman period

name: granito rosso antico minuto
alternate_name: fine red granite, fine red Egyptian granite (granito Egizio carnino minuto)
appearance: Either pink/reddish or light gray; medium- to fine-grained
quarry_location: Southern Egypt, Aswan

name: Granito verde della sedia
alternate_name: lapis ophytes, ofite; "snake-stone"; granito verde della sedia di San Lorenzo (variety 1), granito verde della sedia di San Pietro (variety 2)
appearance: grey/blue/white/green; two varieties, both speckled white and green
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian Desert; Uadi Semnah; Wadi Umm Wikala; mainly exported to Italy
archaeological_sources: rotae: episcopal throne in S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, Paliotto in the Sistine Chapel of S. Maria Maggiore, Flooring of S. Gregorio Magno. Columns: Palazzo Rondinini; Base of the statue of S. Pietro in Vaticano; tile; trapezophori
primary_sources: Harrell posits that Plliny the Elder was perhaps referring to this stone when he described marmor Augusteum; Pliny notes that it derives its name from serpent-like streaks; also mentioned in Natural History, 36.43
notes: Variety 1 is fine- to medium-grained; variety 2 is medium- to coarse-grained
dates_of_use: 1st to 2nd century CE

name: granito verde fiorito di bigio
alternate_name: gray-flowered green granite
appearance: speckled white, pale green and dark green, fine- to medium-grained
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian Desert, Wadi Umm Balad near Gebel Dokhan; mostly exported to Rome
dates_of_use: 1st to c. 4th century CE

name: Granito violetto
alternate_name: Purple granite, Marmor troadense
appearance: Green/biege/white.
quarry_location: Asia Minor: Exine, Monte Cigri Dâg.
archaeological_sources: Columns: S. Stefano Rotondo, S. Gregorio Magno, S. Clemente, S. Prassede, Palazzo dei Conservatori, cripta dei SS. Bonifacio e Alessio. rotae: S. Gregorio Magno, Bases.
dates_of_use: Used since the Classical Period but not exported until the Imperial Period

name: greco scritto
appearance: white/gray/blue; with black speckles
quarry_location: Algeria, Annaba, Cap de Gard.; Hasancavuslar, 19 km NE of Ephesos, Turkey
archaeological_sources: Stones: S. Clemente. Columns: S. Clemente. Capitals, mirrors, cornices, mattonelle.
dates_of_use: Exported inter-regionally in the Roman period

name: Ham Hill Stone
alternate_name: North Perrott Stone; Hamstone
appearance: Distinctive golden/brown colour often with a mottled appearance, sometime gray/buff; medium- to coarse-grained; two varieties: the more prominent Yellow Bed and the darker, more durable Grey Bed
quarry_location: Quarried from around Ham Hill, Somerset, England; local use
archaeological_sources: Walls of the Roman town of Lindinis (modern Ilchester); coffin excavated at Poundbury, Dorchester; carved roof ornament (finial) of a villa at Dewlish, Dorset
notes: Composed of broken shells cemented with calcium carbonate, limonite, and goethite, contains some quartz grains and ooliths
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Kentish ragstone
alternate_name: Kentish Rag
appearance: Contains a bluish-gray, coarse-grained, hard "Ragstone" layer and a gray, "loamy, calcareous, glauconitic" Hassock layer; layers range from 10-90 cm thick
quarry_location: Quarried at Maidstone, NW Kent, Britain; local and regional use, esp. at London; discovered as cargo in a Roman ship at Blackfriars, London
archaeological_sources: Walls of Roman Londinium (modern London), 200 CE; medieval uses include the foundations of St. Paul's Cathedral, military walls, and castles across Kent
notes: 85% calcium carbonate, with quartz and glauconite grains; ranges from a "shelly limestone with scattered sand grains" to a calcareous stone with enoiugh silica to count as sandstone instead of limestone; sometimes confused with the Reigate stone
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Ketton Freestone
appearance: Colour ranges from pale cream to brownish yellow/buff and from pale to warm pink, while a variety known as Ketton Rag sometimes features white veins; medium-grained and well sorted
quarry_location: Quarried around Ketton, Lincolnshire, England
archaeological_sources: Post-Roman Empire: used to build cathedrals, castles, colleges, etc.
notes: Very porous, easy to work, hardening on exposure, and an excellent stone to carve

name: verde ranocchia
alternate_name: green frog, lapis batrachites/Frog stone, serpentina verde ("green serpent"), serpentina moschinata ("mossy serpent"), verde fiorito ("green flower")
appearance: Fine-grained, light yellow-green/dark green;"with swirls of dark blue, grey, white and brown veins"
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian Desert, Wadi Umm Esh
dates_of_use: "Exported from Pharaonic period but always in small quanitities"

name: lapis sarcophagus
alternate_name: stone of Assos
appearance: Maroon-red
quarry_location: Quarried at Assos, in modern Behramkale, Turkey; local and regional use
archaeological_sources: Sarcophagi, not mentioned in structural contexts

name: travertino di Tivoli
alternate_name: lapis tiburtinus, stone of Tivoli
age: Formed about 170,000 years ago and depositing about .47 millimeters per year
appearance: Divided into strata
quarry_location: Fosse di Tivoli, Villa Adriana,  Caprine Tivoli;Acque Albule basin, 30 km east of Rome
archaeological_sources: Temple of Antonino e Faustina ;  Flavian amphitheatre; in the first century BCE, used as a damage-resistant façade for structures made of tuff - e.g., podium of Temple of Portunus (80 - 70 BCE), outer walkway of the Theater of Marcellus (23 - 11 BCE)
primary_sources: Vitruvius (2.7.1-2) groups travertine among the "moderate" (temperatae) stones of Rome, in contrast to the softer tuffs and harder lavas and notes that travertine resists damage from storms and wet conditions; quarries mentioned in Strabo Geography 5.3.11; Pliny relates an anecdote in which Cicero, shown the walls of Chios built with Chian marble, quipped, "I should be much more amazed if you had made it of stone from Tibur."
notes: Composed of 95% calcium carbonate below formations of calcite and aragonite.;Different chemical compositions from each quarry- chart available; 3.99-23.38%, median 8.36%, coefficient of imbibition at 1400 hours 0.77-1.07% by weight, median 0.85% by weight. Resistance to flexion, perpendicular: 10.0-12.7 MPa, median 11.7 MPa. Parallel: 9.5-11.5 MPa, median 10.7 MPa.
dates_of_use: Used from the end of the second century BCE ; earliest evidence dates to 121 BCE, in the Temple of Concord

name: lumachella orientale
alternate_name: lumachella d'egito
appearance: gray
quarry_location: Quarried at Henchir el Kasbat, ancient Thuburbo Maius, Tunisia, and exported widely, mostly to Rome
dates_of_use: Exported after the Augustan period (early 1st century CE)

name: lumachella rosea
appearance: creamy-pink with occasional flecks of red
quarry_location: Quarried at Kairouan, Eastern Tunisia, near Sousse; local and probably regional use, also used locally in Winden, 40 km SE of Vienna, Austria
dates_of_use: Imperial Period in Tunisia, Roman period in Austria

name: bianco e nero antico
alternate_name: marmo d'Aquitania, marmor celticum, bianco e nero antico di Francia, grand Antique o grand Deuil.; possibly the same as petit antique, noir grand antique marble
appearance: black/yellow
quarry_location: France, Pirenei centrali, Aubert.
archaeological_sources: Columns: ciborio in S. Cecilia, cero pasquale in S. Maria Maggiore, Palazzo Barberini. Wall stones: altar of the Capella Paolina in S. Maria Maggiore. Paving stones: apse of S. Paolo fuori le Mura, room of the Muses in Palazzo Rondinini. Tarsie: Chies del Gesù. Piani di tavolo: palazzo Farnese, palazzo Doria Pamphilij. Zoccolature: S. Pietro in Vincoli, Cornices: S. Clemente. Balustrades: S. Sabina. Monument of Alessandro VII in S. Pietro in Vaticano. Sarcophagi.
dates_of_use: Exported regionally during the Roman Imperial Period, later shipped to Rome

name: marmo di Candoglia
alternate_name: Candoglia Rose Italia, Candoglio, Marmo Rosa Valtoce Candoglia
appearance: pink
quarry_location: Quarried at Candoglia, just west of Mergozzo, near Lago Maggiore, Italy; local and probably regional use

name: marmo di Carrara
alternate_name: marmor lunense, marmo di Luni.
appearance: White/grey; blue-gray variety with dark veins (bardiglio)
quarry_location: taly, Tuscany, Apuane Alps, Carrara; Cava del Polvaccio, the Cava dei Fantiscritti, Cava della Carbonera, Canalgrande, Fossacava, Colonnata, Cava Gioia, Bedizzano, Torano, Scalochiello, Monte Strinato, area of 4 km^2; exported over vast territory during Imperial Period; shipped to Rome along the Tiber
archaeological_sources: Used to face tuff masonry; Columns: casa di Mamurra sul Celio, Traiana, Aureliana. Pilasters: S. Peter's, Paving stones in notable basilicas, wall stones in the podium of the Foro di Augusto: Arco di Costantino, acquasantiere (S. Maria in Campo Marzio. Temples: Apollo Sosiano, Saturno, della Concordia). Foro Italico. Ceri pasquali: monumenti: Ara Pacis Augustae, Piramide Cestia. Obelisk in Foro Italico. Statuary, Sarcophagus, Altar, Fountain, Architrave, Capitelli, Bases, Gradini, tarsie.
primary_sources: C. Suetonius Tranquilus, Nero 50; Strabo praises the quarries at Luna, which supply "monolithic slabs and columns" for "most of the superior works of art in Rome and the rest of the cities" [[Geography 5.2.5]]; Pliny posits that the stone composed the columns of the house of Mamurra, "the first person at Rome who covered the whole of the walls of his house with marble" [[NH 36.7]]; also in NH 36.29
dates_of_use: Quarried beginning in the late first century BCE; Continuous use since Roman times

name: granito misio
alternate_name: marmo misio
appearance: Blue/Black/White/Beige
quarry_location: Asia minor, Kozak, Bergama (Mysia); local use
archaeological_sources: Columns: in the Lupa of the Palazzo Senatorio in Campidogllio, S. Pancrazio, colonnette in the Obelisk of S. Peter.

name: marmo rosso di Taormina
alternate_name: Using physical properties of grigio Taormina
appearance: Red-pink
quarry_location: Used locally and quarried from Taormina, NE Sicily
dates_of_use: Imperial Period, maybe earlier

name: marmo Thaso
alternate_name: Thasos-1, Thasos-2; marmor thasium, grechetto duro
appearance: Thasos-1: White, "with large reflective crystals", Thasos-2: white, medium- to coarse-grained
quarry_location: Thasos-1 quarried at Aliki, Thasos, Greece; "widely exported throughout antiquity", Thasos-2 quarried at Cape Vathy, NE Thasos, also widely exported
archaeological_sources: Wall and paving stones. Columns: 2 in the portico of SS. Giovanni and Paolo, "infamous" columns of the Isola Tiberina. Statue of Aphrodite Charis from the Domus Tiberiana. Cippi.
primary_sources: Vitruvius, Architecture: 10.2.15; C. Suetonius Tranquillus, Nero 50; Pliny mentions as an alternative to Parian marble for sculpting [[Natural History 36.5.44]]
dates_of_use: Thasos-2 mostly exported from 3rd century CE onward

name: Mixon Limestone
alternate_name: Alveolina Limestone
appearance: Cream/yellow; poorly sorted, coarse-grained, with an uneven texture
quarry_location: Local use around Sussex, quarried from the Mixon reef, which now lies 1.5 miles off the coast of Selsey Bill, West Sussex, southern England; in Roman times, this site was on land, and archaeologists have found the alleged remains of a Roman fort and cannon balls; exported regionally
archaeological_sources: Building and foundation stone: stone facing of the west wing of Fishbourne Palace, several buildings in Chichester
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: nero antico
alternate_name: marmor taenarium; nero antico chiota
appearance: black/white/grey
quarry_location: Tunisia, Numidia, Chemtou, Gebel Aziza. Greece, Peloponnese, Capo Tenaro, Capo Matapan, Chios.; Mani Peninsula; Asia Minor, Adapazari; Italy, Lazio, Palombino.;  Quarried at Ain el-Ksir near Chemtou, used locally and maybe regionally; Quarried at Djebel Aziz, central NE Tunisia
archaeological_sources: Columns: S. Maria in Araecoeli, S. Lorenzo in Lucina. [[1, 318]] Paving stones: S. Pietro in Vincoli, S. Giovanni in Laterano. Tables: palazzo Altemps. Statue: erme in the Museum Nazionale Romano.
primary_sources: Strabo, Geography: 8.5.7; Pliny the Elder is perhaps referring to it when he classes the "Taenarian stone" among "black stones…held in much the same esteem as the marbles" [[HN 36.29]]
dates_of_use: Possibly exported from Cape Tainaro "in Roman period and earlier",Exported from Djebel Aziz during the Imperial Period, esp. to Rome

name: Newbald Stone
appearance: Cream-colored, compact; contains medium rounded grains (ooliths) cemented by "patches of crystalline calcite"
quarry_location: Quarried around Newbald, England, near Kingston-upon Hull, East Yorkshire; used for building construction in York (Roman city of Eboracum)

name: Occhio di pavone
alternate_name: marmor sagarium; m. triptonicum, marmo occhiuto, ossipetro
appearance: red/orange/white; white veins, pale gray shades
quarry_location: Asia Minor, Izmit, Kutluca; quarried at Taskisiği, near Adapazari in Bithynia, modern Turkey
archaeological_sources: Columns: S. Maria della Minerva, Vatican Library. Paving stones: S. Clemente. crustae: S. Maria in Via Lata. Mirrors: S. Pancrazio. Sculptures: Conserved palla in niche at S. Maria in Trastevere. Thrones, Sarcophagi, basins
dates_of_use: Exported between regions, Imperial Period (small amounts)

name: Pavonazzetto
alternate_name: marmor phrygium o docimium o synnadicum, Phrygian marble; Docimitus
appearance: blue/white/orange; "pavonazetto" refers to the thin gray/purple veins
quarry_location: Asia minor, Iscehisar, Afyon; quarried in a 0.24 km^2 area near Dokimeion (Iscehisar), Exported to Milet or Ephesos by way of Synnada, Apameia, and Laodiceia ad Lycum; Çakırsaz, Upper Tembris valley, modern Turkey, light green variety at Krokeai, Southern Lakonia, Greece; exported inter-regionally ; shipped to Rome in slabs or pillars
archaeological_sources: Paving stones, often in opus sectile: Temple of Mars Ultor, Temple della Concordia, Basilica Giulia, Basilica Aemilia, Pantheon, Trajanic Forum, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, Vittoriano. Wall stones: Pantheon, Vestibule of S. Giovanni in Laterano, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura. Statuary: Daci a Palazzo dei Conservatori. Columns: Basilica Ulpia, Pantheon, S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Clemente. Bases: Pantheon. Curia, sarcophagi.
primary_sources: Strabo compares its variety of colors to that of "alabastrite marble"; Pliny mentions the Phrygian columns of the Basilica of Paulus [[Natural History 36.24; Pliny the Elder, Natural History 5.29
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Pentelic marble
alternate_name: pentelico, lithos penteleikos o pentelesios, lithos pentelesin, marmor pentelicum; Dionyssos Kokkinara, Dionissos Penteli, Bianco Dionissos, Pentelicon
appearance: White; fine-grained, "honey-yellow shade"
quarry_location: Greece, Athens, Mount Pentelico
archaeological_sources: Wall stones: Pantheon, Arch of Titus. Paving stones: capella lituana in S. Paolo fuori le Mura. Columns: tempio Rotondo nel Foro Boario, tempio di Giove Capitolino. Propileus: Portico of Ottavia. Capitals: S. Urbano alla Caffarella. Architraves: Basilica Ulpia, S. Urbano alla Caffarella. Statues
notes: 97-98% calcite
dates_of_use: Local use from the Archaic period, vast exportation during Roman times

name: bekhen-stone
alternate_name: pietra bekhen, lapis basanites, basanites lithos, basaniti lapidis,basanite, basalt,grovacca; basalte verde antico
appearance: black/grey
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian desert/ Mons Basanites/ Uadi Hammamat
archaeological_sources: Statues: 12 in the Throne Room of the Flavian Palace, bust of Jove in the Villa Albani. Urns: Baptistery of S. Giovanni in Laterano, S. Croce in Jerusalem. Basins: Octagonal courtyard in the Vatican City.
dates_of_use: "Exported in Roman Imperial Period but very rare"

name: pietra paesina
quarry_location: Used locally and quarried from Valdarno, just south of Florence, Italy
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: granito a morviglione
alternate_name: porfido bigio/gray porphyry, granito a morviglione, granito blu dell'Esterel, Frejus porphyry.
appearance: grey/pink/black/white; white, pink, gray, blue specks
quarry_location: France, Var Boulouris, Sant Raphael-Frejus; France, Dramont, just east of Boulouris, Les Petits Carous, just north of Boulouris, "used locally from Archaic period, exported further sporadically and then only to Rome"
archaeological_sources: Columns: Baths of Caracalla, S. Peter's, floor stones, mattonelle.

name: porfido nero
alternate_name: porfido antico, porfido Egiziano, lapis porphyrites melanos, black porphyry; porfido nero grafico
appearance: black groundmass, pale green/white crystals
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian desert, Gebel Dokhan (Mons Porphyrites)
notes: Exported in small quantities
dates_of_use: 1st to early 5th century CE

name: Porfido rosso antico
alternate_name: Ancient red porphryry, lapis porphyrites thebaicus, porphyrites, lithos romainon, Imperial Porphyry, Porphyrite.
appearance: red/pink
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian desert; Gebel Dokhan (Mons Porphyrites); over 9 km^2
archaeological_sources: Sarcophagi: S. Costanza, S. Maria in Aracoeli. Columns: Temple of Romulus in the Forum, Pantheon. Floor: S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, S. Clemente, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Pietro in Vaticano. Ciboria: S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, S. Giovanni in Fonte, S. Crisogono in Trastevere. Baptismal fonts: S. Pietro in Vatocano. Basins, marquetry.
primary_sources: Was Pliny referring to this stone when he described a red Egyptian porphyry as "not very highly approved of" since it was introduced under emperor Claudius?
dates_of_use: Inscription dating to 18 CE , with signs of occupation through the fourth century CE ; or early fifth century CE

name: porfido serpentino nero
alternate_name: black serpent porphyry
appearance: black aphanitic groundmass with pale gray crystals; "green shade and white flecks"
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian Desert, Wadi Umm Towat near Gebel Dokhan
notes: Very rare
dates_of_use: c. 1st to 2nd century CE

name: porfido serpentino antico
alternate_name: porfido verde antico/Ancient green porphyry, lapis lacedaemonius, krokeatis lithos, serpentino, verde di Laconia o di Sparta.;porfido verde di Grecia
appearance: Green/brown; another variety is lighter green pavonazzetto
quarry_location: Greece, Laconia, Sparta, Krokeai/Stephanià.
archaeological_sources: Colonnine: baptistery of S. Giovanni in Laterano. Paving stones, also in opus sectile (Curia, S. Maria in Aracoeli, SS Giovanni e Paolo, S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, S. Pietro in Vincoli, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, Vittoriano. Paving stones: Nympheum of Egeria), Capitals: Ciborio di S. Saba, Mattonelle, Cornices.
dates_of_use: Used from the Mycenean period but only exported inter-regionally in the Roman Imperial period

name: porfido verde Egiziano
alternate_name: Egyptian green porphyry, lapid hieracitis ("hawk stone"); porfido verde oliva
appearance: green-black groundmass with pale green and white crystals
quarry_location: Eastern Egyptian desert, Gebel Dokhan (Mons Porphyrites)
notes: Exported in small quantities
dates_of_use: 1st to early 5th century CE

name: Portasanta
alternate_name: marmor chium
appearance: Red/Purple/White; large white/gray/red crystals, white/pink bands
quarry_location: Grecia, Mare Egeo, Isola di Chios, Latomion, quarried from Mount Pelinnaeus; similar variety (rosa Portugues) used locally/regionally in Portugal
archaeological_sources: Paving stones: Basilica Aemilia and Giulia, Atrium Vestae, Trajanic Forum, S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Maria della Vittoria, S. Sabina, S. Gregorio Magno. thresholds: Tempio della Concordia, Stadio del Palatino. Columns: Largo Argentina, altar of S. Sebastion and of the Presentazione in St. Peter's, S. Agnese fuori le Mura, S. Pietro in Vincoli, cappella di S. Domenico in S. Clemente, S. Gregorio Magno. Jambs: Porta Santa di S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Giovanni in Laterano, S. Pietro, S. Maria Maggiore, S. Maria dell'Anima. Fountain basins: Piazza Navona and Piazza Colonna. Bases: S. Pietro in Vincolo: Stele; trapezophori.
primary_sources: Strabo refers to a marble quarry on Chios
dates_of_use: used in Rome starting in Augustan period, esp. under Trajan and Hadrian

name: marmo di Proconneso
alternate_name: proconnesio, marmor proconnesium. Cyzium. Marmo cipolla.; Neuris, Proconnesus
appearance: Gray/White; medium-grained, some with pale blue bands
quarry_location: Asia minor, Isola di Marmara, Proconnesos; Used in nearby cities, esp. Cyzicus
archaeological_sources: Columns and capitals: Colosseum. Sarcophagi: the so-called "Grande Ludovisi" in Palazzo Altemps. Floors, Altars, trabeations. [[1, 314]] Façade of the Mausoleum at Halicarnassus, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World [[Pliny, NH 36.6.47]]
primary_sources: Strabo, Geography: 7.fragments.55, 13.1.16; Pliny the Elder, Natural History: 5.44, 36.6.47; Vitruvius, Architecture:10.2.15
dates_of_use: Local use from Archaic period; 2nd century CE onward exported widely

name: Purbeck marble
alternate_name: Purbeck (Royal) Blue, Purbeck Green
appearance: Dark brown/black, with green/yellow/brown specks; or, blue-gray/green tinted with green/red coarse-grained, hard, very smooth, poorly sorted, containing the fossilized shells of viviparus carniferus
quarry_location: Exported across the region from the Isle of Purbeck, SE Dorset, Britain
archaeological_sources: Columns, moldings, veneers, inlays, flooring, inscriptions, tesserae, and small objects, including the Temple of Claudius (c. 54 CE) and a 1st century CE tombstone in Dorset; popular feature of Medieval churches
notes: Knowles distinguishes between two varieties: blue-gray and green. Both were apparently quarried by Romans.
dates_of_use: Soon after Roman occupation in 43 CE

name: Quarr Featherbed
petrographic_details: Bioclastic Limestone from the Bembridge Beds
appearance: Yellow-brown to gray-green; contains lots of small shell fragments ranging from 3 to 6 mm
quarry_location: Quarried from Quarr Wood, Binstead, on the Isle of Wight, southern England; local and regional use
archaeological_sources: Parts of Portchester Castle (i.e., the original Roman fort?)
dates_of_use: Imperial Period

name: Sarsen Stone
alternate_name: Bridestone, Druid Stone, Grey Wether, Heathstone
appearance: Ranges from gray to light brown, sometimes pink or blue-gray; fine-grained and well cemented, composed of pure quartz crystals and iron-filled cavities
quarry_location: downs and heaths of southern England, particularly the Marlborough Downs, esp. around Wiltshire, and to a lesser extent in Dorset, Hampshire, Oxfordshire, and Kent
archaeological_sources: The only Roman example Knowles gives is of a set of rotary quernstones (used to grind grain), but evidence from other eras indicates that the stone was also used for large monuments, including Stonehenge. Difficult for masonry as they were hard to cut; could not be split into uniform blocks until the 1800s
notes: Not quarried but instead "taken from the surface debris scattered over the Downs", in blocks up to 6 m long

name: Swithland Slate
appearance: Dark blue/gray, sometimes with shades of green; compact, fine-grained, hard, and smooth
quarry_location: Quarried around Leicester, central England
archaeological_sources: Roofing and walling; also used for tombstones
notes: Composed of white mica, quartz, chlorite, and other minerals

name: Verde antico
alternate_name: marmor atracium o thessalicum; lapis atracius.; verde orientale, cipollino verde antico, serpentin marmor
appearance: Green/white/grey; darker patches and white/green crystals
quarry_location: Greece, Thessaly, Chasabali
archaeological_sources: Columns: Foro Romano, Palazzo Farnese, S. Agnese in Agone, S. Maria Maddalene in Campo Marzio, S. Giovanni in Laterano, Confessional of S. Lorenzo fuori le Mura, S. Sabine. Wall stones: S. Paolo fuori le Mura, S. Giovanni in Laterano, S. Sabina, S. Pietro in Vincoli, S. Clemente, S. Maria Maddalena in Campo Marzio, S. Gregorio Magno, SS. Giovanni e Paolo. Paving stones: Vittoriano. Sarcophagus of S. Sisto in S. Maria Maggiore. Basins, Statues.
dates_of_use: Exported inter-regionally by the 2nd century AD and widely in Late Antiquity

name: White Grinshill
appearance: Whitish grey, creamy buff colour with brown speckles; quarried alongside a red/pink variety; medium-grained, hard, rough
quarry_location: Possibly quarried around Clive, Shropshire, England
archaeological_sources: Possibly used to build the walls at the Roman town of Viroconium (modern Wroxeter)
notes: Minerals: quartz, microline, muscovite mica, feldspar, granite, flint, quartzite, iron ore
dates_of_use: No archaeological evidence for quarries during Roman times, although it is thought that they existed; the earliest evidence dates to the 10th century CE

name: Tufo Giallo di Sacrofano
quarry_location: Monti Sabatini

name: Tufo Terrosco con Pomici Bianche
quarry_location: Monti Sabatini

name: Tufo Pisolitico di Trigoria
quarry_location: Alban Hills
